subject: Re: Categories in 4.8, how can I avoid specifying classes in @Suite.SuiteClasses

messageBody:
Hi!

I implemented something like this and posted it on github.
Essentially, the modified Suite matches a regexp against all classes in the class path and executes those matching (this is there is one to exclude others, too). However, this only works for entire classes and not for individual tests.

Cheers,
Georg

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "yme0987654321" <yme0987654321@...> wrote:
>
> One way to do this is to subclass the Suite runner and pass the array of classes to the Suite constructor. How you generate that array from the classes available on the classpath is not something JUnit provides special help with, but you can look at the Reflections project to help you with that:
>
> http://code.google.com/p/reflections/
>
> I haven't tried categories with the sub-classing method, but I would be surprised if it didn't work.
>
> Yishai
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, baardl <bard.lind@> wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi.
> >
> > I have been trying to use TestNG for a while, but found the transition a bit
> > too hard :-)
> >
> > Categories in junit is looking promising, but there is two things that stops
> > me from implementing this into
> > our current project.
> > 1. How can I run tests in an category, without needing to add all my test
> > classes to the @... annotation?
> > Needing to add a new testclass to a suite will over time guarantee that we
> > loose (forget to add) some tests.
> >
> > 2. Will there be a Maven 2 support for running test in a single category?
> > Like
> > -Dtest.category=SlowTest,FastTest
> >
